title: U.S. begins to pare back Hong Kong's special status amid scrutiny over security law | CBC News
description: The U.S. began eliminating Hong Kong's special status under U.S. law on Monday, halting defence exports and restricting the territory's access to high technology products as China prepares new Hong Kong security legislation.
content: The U.S. began eliminating Hong Kong's special status under U.S. law on Monday, halting defence exports and restricting the territory's access to high technology products as China prepares new Hong Kong security legislation.The U.S. move comes as the top decision-making body of China's parliament deliberates a draft national security law for Hong Kong that pro-democracy activists in the city fear will be used to eliminate dissent and tighten Beijing's control."The Chinese Communist Party's decision to eviscerate Hong Kong's freedoms has forced the Trump administration to re-evaluate its policies toward the territory," U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said.The Chinese embassy in Washington did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Last month, U.S. President Donald Trump responded to China's plans for the security law by saying he was initiating a process to eliminate special economic treatment that has allowed Hong Kong to remain a global financial centre since its handover by Britain in 1997.Trump stopped short of calling for an immediate end to privileges but said the moves would affect the full range of U.S. agreements with Hong Kong, from an extradition treaty to export controls on dual-use technologies and more — "with few exceptions."The U.S. Commerce Department said it was suspending "preferential treatment to Hong Kong over China, including the availability of export-license exceptions."Further actions to eliminate Hong Kong's status were being evaluated, the departmemt said.In 2018, $432.7 million US of goods were shipped to Hong Kong under a Commerce Department exception, mostly relating to encryption, software and technology.Pompeo said the United States, effective Monday, was ending exports of defence equipment to Hong Kong and will also take steps to end the export of dual-use technologies, which have both commercial and military uses.Last year, the Department of State approved approximately $2.4 million US worth of controlled defence articles and services to Hong Kong government authorities, of which approximately $1.4 million US worth was shipped, according State Department records."The United States is forced to take this action to protect U.S. national security," Pompeo said. "We can no longer distinguish between the export of controlled items to Hong Kong or to mainland China."The announcements come at a time of intensified U.S. rhetoric against Beijing as Trump campaigns for re-election in November. Opinion polls have shown voters increasingly embittered toward China, especially over the coronavirus, which began there.

title: TRANSCRIPT: SANCTIONED - EPISODE 7 | CBC Radio
description: Full-text transcript for Sanctioned episode seven
content: Sanctioned - The Arrest Warrant Host: Stephen Quinn Announcer: This is a CBC Podcast. [music: somber] Stephen: Previously, on Sanctioned. Huawei Chief Financial Officer, Meng Wanzhou is arrested at Vancouver International Airport in December 2018. She's accused of fraud in the United States, and later released on $10 million bail, meanwhile, two Canadians are accused of spying on China and a third is sentenced to death. Politicians in Canada, China, and the U.S. are drawn into a war of words and actions and Huawei's role in the next generation of wireless technology is questioned. [music: somber] [sound: outdoor din] Stephen: On the afternoon of the first nice day of spring, a black SUV pulls into a quiet street in the tony Vancouver neighbourhood of Shaughnessy. Another black SUV is already parked on the road. Two suited men are inside, they watch as the first vehicle pulls in front of a gated, twenty-year-old house. A slight Chinese woman steps out of the SUV. Across the street, another woman, a journalist, holds a camera.  [sound: camera clicks] Stephen: She's been standing there for hours. Her interest perks up as the vehicle pulls in front of her, blocking a view of the gate and the house beyond. [music: somber] Stephen: The female passenger from the SUV stands on the sidewalk, surveying the property. It's May 11th, 2019, and Meng Wanzhou is moving house and the two men keeping watch for Meng aren't the only security in the area. The home of the American consul is nearby and it's also guarded around the clock. It is an interesting situation that a woman the U.S. wants to incarcerate, and the official representative of the United States, are polite neighbours in Vancouver, a city that has become an unlikely battleground in a fight between global superpowers. Teeth aren't bared, weapons aren't drawn between enemies in a place like this. After all, we're in Shaughnessy, a stately clutch of mansions and old money located in the heart of the city's west side, where streets like Matthews, Angus and Marguerite are named for Canadian Pacific Railway executives who built the neighbourhood a century ago, but it's a fight all the same.  [music: somber] Stephen: And as the chief financial officer of the world's largest telecommunications equipment maker eyes her new home, Meng Wanzhou's address isn't the only thing that's about to change. Her lawyers are preparing to attack, her company will face a threat that could shake the order of the digital universe. Canada's economy will feel China's wrath and the order of the political world, or at least the lines between east and west will be tested by unrest in Meng's other home, Hong Kong. [music: somber] Stephen: I'm Stephen Quinn and you're listening to Sanctioned: The Arrest of a Telecom Giant, a CBC Vancouver original podcast about Huawei Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou, and her fight against possible extradition and jailing in the United States for allegedly violating economic sanctions against Iran. It's a journey deep into the world of global business and politics, up front deals and allegations of back room skullduggery in the battle to dominate the economies of the future, not to mention the extraordinary wealth and power of a few of the world's most influential players. Stephen: We launched in April 2019 with six episodes that covered the time from Meng's arrest in Vancouver on December 1st 2018 to the growing fallout from her situation a few months later, including the arrest of two Canadians in China for allegations of spying and the sentencing of a third Canadian to death for drug trafficking. We promised we'd be back, and that time is now, as Meng prepares for court proceedings ahead of an extradition hearing set to begin in January of 2020. A lot has changed since Sanctioned first dropped, and if you haven't listened to those first six episodes, now might be a good time to go back and add them to your feed, but since we last spoke, relations between Canada and China have hit an all-time low. The trade battle between the United States and China has only intensified and a flood of new details about Meng's arrest have emerged. Stephen: Over the next two episodes, we'll examine the ever expanding ripple effects of Meng's arrest as President Donald Trump announces new measures to keep Huawei out of the U.S. technological supply stream, and we'll zoom in on three crucial hours in this story, the hours immediately after Meng stepped off her flight from Hong Kong and before she was arrested by the RCMP in Vancouver. Hours in which her lawyers claim Canadian and U.S. authorities colluded to violate Meng's rights so badly that they want the case against her tossed, but we'll begin where so much of the case has played out in the legal arena where Meng Wanzhou emerges with a new look, a new strategy, and a bid to reshape the narrative. This is Sanctioned, Episode 7: The Arrest Warrant. [music: somber] Stephen: The pose of the woman in this grainy video would be familiar to anyone who has ever been called aside for secondary inspection at an airport. Tired after a long flight, Meng Wanzhou is seen standing with her hands in the pockets of a dark tracksuit, comfortable wear for the long flight from Hong Kong. She's at a counter in an area of YVR that, if they're lucky, most travellers never see. Eight pieces of luggage are piled on a trolley nearby. [sound: The goings-on of a luggage search] Stephen: Two men in dark uniforms sift through Meng's bags, as they ask her questions. They are Canada Border Services Agents, and they can seize and examine the items of anyone trying to enter the country. They don't need warrants and they're not required to warn anyone about the legal consequences of volunteering information. It's those powers and the use of them that will come into question as Meng Wanzhou's extradition hearing nears, because her lawyers, who filed this video with the court, claim that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police conspired with the border agency to detain Meng for more than three hours before officially arresting her. Stephen: The reason? According to the defence, it's so the RCMP could mount a covert criminal investigation against Meng using the CBSA to detain and question her,  all allegedly, at the direction of the American FBI.  [music: somber] Stephen: CBC reporter Jason Proctor has been following the court proceedings. He's with me now. Hello, Jason. Jason Proctor: Hello, Stephen.  Stephen: So, this video was actually released by B.C. Supreme Court Associate Chief Justice Heather Holmes in mid August. What happened in court that day? Jason: Well, yes, so the video was actually released nearly half a year after surveillance cameras captured those first, very tense moments that Meng spent on Canadian soil and months after she made her last in-person court appearance before Holmes, So this was actually the first time that we got a look at Meng Wanzhou for quite a few months, and to be honest, her appearance was quite different from the way it had been previously, when she'd sort of been wearing what looked like that same tracksuit that you see her in, in this video. Stephen: Right, and how is she different then? Jason:  Well, she kind of traded those floppy hats and casual wear of these previous court dates for a look that many people thought was much more fitting for a woman who is the chief financial officer of a multi billion dollar company so she wore a designer dress, you know, hair kind of flowing over her shoulders, held back by this stylish silver headband. I checked the logo, she was clutching a small Chanel bag, kind of gold chain on black material and and she, you know, with all of this, makes her way into the court at the side of one of the guards that she's still paying, if you recall, to maintain this kind of virtual jail around her that she's agreed to live in 24/7 as part of a ten million dollar bail agreement. Stephen: And an ankle monitoring bracelet to complete the ensemble. Jason:  Exactly. This was actually one of, the kind of fascinating things, is she's wearing this dress and just below the, kind of hem of the dress, which is just above her ankle, and these kind of low heeled sandals, you see this very solid ankle monitor which is, you know, cemented onto her leg to basically make sure that she maintains this boundary and a limitation of her movements around Vancouver, while she's under the direction of the court. Stephen: Alright. Now, this court appearance that you attended, this would, I guess begin the process that would culminate with the release of the video, but there were also other notes and documents that were gathered by Meng's lawyers to support the claim that authorities had violated her rights from the outset. What are Meng's lawyers basing that claim on? Jason: Well, so they say it was an abuse of process, what happened to her at the airport in those crucial first three hours and Scott Fenton, a top tier defender who flew out from Toronto to join Meng's legal team, told Justice Holmes he believed it was serious enough to warrant a stay of proceedings, in other words to toss the case  and set Meng free. I should say Scott Fenton is renowned for his knowledge of fraud and of cases dealing with the corruption of public officials and with Meng's case, he claimed the CBSA, that's Canada Border Services Agency, the RCMP, and the FBI weren't the only ones at fault here. He also pointed a finger at U.S. President Donald Trump.  [music: somber] Stephen: Donald Trump's shadow has loomed over Meng's case from almost the beginning, ever since he suggested she could be used as a bargaining chip if it would get the U.S. a better trade deal with China. [news clips play] Reporter: Here's what the president said in an interview late yesterday with Reuters about the Huawei CFO, Meng Wanzhou. He said, if I think it's good for the country, if I think it's good for what will be, certainly, the largest trade deal ever made, which is a very important thing, what's good for national security, I would certainly intervene if I thought it was necessary. Reporter 2: He also said that he, that, ah, he would,  the release of Meng could be part of a broader trade deal with China. So, President Trump really throwing a bit of a wrench into this case, essentially confirming that Meng Wanzhou is a bargaining chip. Reporter 3:  Meng's lawyer says she's being held hostage as part of a U.S. trade spat with China, but U.S. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin in a Tuesday interview on Fox News said the pursuit against Huawei had nothing to do with trade negotiations. The Chinese government however doesn't agree. Stephen: But as the months following Meng's arrest begin to add up, so did the weight of U.S. pressure on Huawei. The company had already been excluded from bidding on American government contracts, a move that would effectively freeze them from the U.S. 5G grid, but in May, Donald Trump took another extraordinary step. [news clips play] Reporter: The Trump administration is cracking down on Chinese telecom giant Huawei.There are two specific actions that were taken yesterday. The first one came from the White House, that executive order essentially enabling the U.S. to ban telecommunications equipment from quote, "foreign adversaries". They didn't specifically single out China or Huawei, but this more significant movement yesterday came from the Department of Commerce, adding Huawei to a so-called entity list. Reporter 2:  That effectively prevents it from buying American parts, unless it has U.S. government approval, they say. So, they are definitely targeting Huawei with the Commerce Department action, the commerce secretary is gonna have a lot of discretion in how to approve and process all of this. Stephen: Now, if the phrase, "Entity List" sounds bland and bureaucratic, the names on the list are anything but. There are 300 pages worth of firms and people accused of being at risk of funding "activities contrary to U.S. interests" and list spans "entities" range from Afghanistan, to Vietnam, to China. [clip of Paul Evans speaking] Paul Evans: See, Huawei is, in some ways, corporate enemy number 1 in the context of American thinking. I am Paul Evans, a professor of Asian international affairs and the school of public policy and global affairs at the University of British Columbia. I just returned from Washington, where I met with think tanks and government agencies on the matter of the U.S. China relationship, which I think many of us see in a spiral downwards, at this stage. Five years ago, Americans who were looking at the rise of China, it's important, they had some criticisms they had some worries on the military side, but five years ago the view was, China can't innovate, because of its political system and because of its state led economic system, it could imitate, it could steal, but it could not innovate. Paul: Viewed now, it's exactly the reverse. United States is afraid of a China that can innovate and that it can innovate at world class levels. 5G technology is just one example of artificial intelligence, quantum computing robotics. Suddenly, this is a China that can innovate and the kicker is that it can innovate because it has an authoritarian political system and state led economy. Stephen:  Well, now that Huawei and 68 of its affiliates are on the entity list and deemed a potential threat to U.S. national security, the Chinese telecom giant will be banned from even buying parts and components from American companies without U.S. approval. Huawei responded by shrugging the problem off. [Huawei representative and affiliates speaking in Mandarin] Voicer: Our business in the United States is not that big. Due to our global operations, any change in one country has little impact on our global business.  Voicer 2: The U.S. is using its national power to constantly and deliberately smear and suppress certain Chinese companies by all means. This is not honorable nor is it just. People can clearly see their intentions. [somber music] Stephen: But the implications are far reaching, Huawei is the world's second largest producer of Android phones. Being cut off from U.S. technology would mean running without American operating systems. On a basic level that means a phone or mobile device without Google, of course, Huawei has the ability to design its own operating systems with China's own version of Google, but experts began warning that, if taken to its natural conclusion, Huawei's place on the entity list could signal the beginning of a world divided into East and West when it comes to digital devices and instead of the increased globalization that has marked the past few decades of technological growth, the world could be moving towards a new kind of cold war, one that would be played out through smartphones and tablets. Stephen: Trump almost immediately suspended the designation, opting instead to re-consider Huawei's place as a pariah, every three months. Now, bear in mind that at this point, China and the United States were already locked in a trade war and if anything, the tensions in that spat didn't appear to be decreasing, instead, they were ramping up. [news clips play] Reporter: There is heightened tension tonight between the world's two largest economies. President Trump is now threatening more tariffs on China. Donald Trump: We had a deal with China. It was 95 percent there and then my representatives, as you know, Secretary Mnuchin and  Robert Lighthizer our ambassador, Lighthizer, they went to China and they were told the things that were fully agreed to, we're not going to get anymore. They're going to un-agree to them. That's not acceptable. I said good, that's fine, put on the tariffs. Reporter 2: It looks like they've gone ahead and done it and increased the tariffs to 25 percent. How will China retaliate? Woman:  Just after the tariffs went into effect, the Chinese MOFCOM published a post on its website, saying that China deeply regrets for U.S. decision to increase tariffs and China will have to take a necessary counter measures. Stephen: So, as experts began fretting about the possibility of greater damage to both economies. Any bargaining chip in the trade battle would be a big deal for the U.S. Meng's lawyer, Scott Fenton, knew all this when he stood up in court in August to call Trump's original comments about his client "intimidating and corrosive"  Stephen: And so Meng's legal team worked to draw up a narrative that would place the actions of those border guards who searched her bags on December 1st within that greater context of a global economic battle, a battle where a meddling U.S. president is determined to humble the Chinese economic giant and its unsuspecting chief financial officer. [music: somber] [sound: pages flipping]  Stephen: The notes of the RCMP officers tasked with arresting Meng Wanzhou indicate that they knew the case would be complicated from the outset. "Female never flies to USA,'' wrote one officer. "Do not want to alert online for flight manifest", wrote another. "No trust." Stephen: Those notes were released at the same time as the airport video, fleshing out the details of the defence team's allegations. They also show that the plan had originally been to enter Meng's plane after it landed and to arrest her at that time. After all, a judge had given them a warrant that justified her immediate arrest, but instead, Meng was led by border guards to that secondary inspection area in the airport. In the video footage, Meng is flicking her hair away from her shoulders as a female guard trails. She's questioned about her business activities by Acting CBSA Superintendent Surjit Dhillon. According to his notes, the questioning went like this: [clip of Dhillon speaking]  Surjit Dhillon: I asked the subject if her company sold products in the United States.The subject stated, "no we do not." The subject was then asked if her company sold products in countries that they should not. The subject appeared confused by the questions. I rephrased the question and asked the subject if her company sold products or did business in Iran. The subject initially stated, "I don't know."  I reminded the subject that she is the CFO of a multibillion dollar company and that it would be hard for me to believe that she wouldn't know these details about her company. The subject stated that her company does have an office in Iran. Stephen: So, was this the smoking gun that RCMP were hoping to secure at the direction of the FBI? An admission that Huawei had an office in Iran? Jason Proctor is back with us and certainly a lot of American news outlets treated it that way. Jason: Yes, you saw that is a headline coming out of this trove of documents, you know, hundreds of pages worth of notes of border guards transcripts of interviews, all kinds of things and remember this all goes back to-- and  the reason why the possible admission of anything with regards to Iran is so important, because it was Huawei's activities in Iran that were the basis for Meng's arrest and the allegation that she had lied to banks about Huawei's alleged relationship with Skycom, a firm that was said to be a hidden subsidiary for the company doing business in Iran that violated U.S. sanctions.  Jason: So, Meng's lawyers claim that during the three hours before she was arrested, Canadian authorities were actually in constant contact with their American counterparts and they were ordered to seize Meng's mobile devices because you know they were allegedly told to obtain Meng's passwords, again all according to the defense and to question her, all in the aid of trying to get the information that could help send her to jail. Stephen: And Meng's lawyers also released a transcript of an interview with an RCMP officer. Jason: Exactly, and this is one of the documents I found most fascinating, just because it reveals more than we ever knew about these first moments where she's told, you are under arrest and this is what's going on. This was a transcript of an interview with RCMP Constable Winston Yep. He's the officer who obtained the provisional warrant to arrest  Meng at the behest of the United States, and again, this is the record of the moment at which Meng is officially taken into police custody and these wheels of justice begin turning. [music: somber] Stephen: It was twelve minutes past two on December 1st, 2018. Constable Winston Yep and Meng sat in an office at the airport with another officer, Constable Dawn But. In a halting speech full of ums and ahs, Constable Yep tells Meng why she has been arrested. Constable But translates into Mandarin. [clip of Dawn But's voicer speaking] Winston Yep: [speaking: English] Dawn But: [translating into Mandarin] Because in the United States, uh, you have committed fraud, uh, we're arresting you and then you will be sent back to the United States.  Stephen: The conversation switches back and forth between English and Mandarin, as the two officers read the warrant to Meng. Yep asks if she has any questions. Meng responds in Mandarin. [clip of Meng's voicer speaking] Meng Wanzhou: [speaking: Mandarin] Translator: I'm not clear on what has happened. Why would I have an arrest warrant, and I have got involved in fraud? Stephen: The officers attempt to explain, but Meng is slow to understand. Finally, she says...  [clip of Meng's voicer speaking] Meng: [speaking: Mandarin]  Translator: You're saying, because of my company, you're arresting me, you're saying, you're going to arrest me? And then send me to the United States? Stephen: This is Meng Wanzhou before she has a lawyer, so the two constables begin explaining how she can go about getting one, either through her company or through legal aid. Fast forward to May 2019, and Meng now has not one lawyer, but four, and all of them are present in the courtroom. David Martin, Scott Fenton, Richard Peck, and Eric Gottardi, all jointly sign their legal briefs with the kind of flourish you'd be more likely to see on a communique from the G7, rather than a memorandum in support of an application. But they've come up with a strategy to match Meng's more business-like look, and her move to her multi-million dollar mansion. It's matched by the more aggressive pose struck by Huawei's media spokesman as well. Stephen: Benjamin Howes stands on the steps of the courthouse after the proceedings are done for the day, and echoes the arguments that the lawyers inside the court have just made. [clip of Benjamin Howes speaking] Benjamin Howes: From the beginning, Huawei has expressed extreme confidence in Ms. Meng's innocence. We have maintained that her U.S. ordered arrest was an unlawful abuse of process, one guided by political considerations and tactics, not by the rule of law. Canadians value the rule of law, and the Charter of Rights. Law enforcement officials are expected to follow the rules at all times, in all cases and for all people, citizens and visitors alike. We have trust in the Canadian judicial process and we look forward to seeing Ms. Meng's freedom restored. Stephen: And so the stage is set for the battle to come, and like so many Canadian legal fights, the Charter of Rights and Freedoms appears likely to play a central role.It's the document that underpins much of modern Canadian life, from the right to live a life free of persecution or discrimination, to the right to end one's own life. The Charter is part of the legacy of former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, coming into effect in 1982. Pierre Trudeau, of course, was the father of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who now has to deal with the growing economic and political repercussions of his government's decision to arrest Meng Wanzhou on behalf of the United States and away from the courtroom, those pressures are mounting. [advertisement for canola plays] Man: Thinking about canola, 50 years ago, even 20 years ago, it was that close to being considered as a weed. Woman: It's the most profitable crop for us producers to grow. Stephen: Canada is the world's number one exporter of canola, a crop described as the country's greatest agricultural success story. The vast prairie fields of Saskatchewan and Manitoba are ablaze with yellow flowers of the plant, whose name is literally a combination of the worlds Canada and oil. It produces one of the world's healthiest vegetable oils, high-protein animal feed, and biofuel, and as China looked for new ways to show its displeasure with Canada's role in the arrest of a Chinese business icon, canola must have made a very tempting target. Stephen: Canola seed exports to China were worth $2.8 billion in 2018, but then suddenly, China announced that it had concerns with pests in the products of two of Canada's main seed exporters, placing a ban on imports to China. [clip of conference] Woman: Speaker, we've just learned that China will stop purchasing Canadian canola wheat, peas, linseed, and canola meal. This is devastating news for our farmers. More than 40 percent of Canadian canola alone is currently sold to China. The loss of this market is catastrophic and it will cost billions of dollars to our economy. Man: We're really puzzled by the problem in the first place, we are very confident of the quality of Canadian canola on international markets. Man 2: We've heard very clearly that there is a significant interest in sending a high level delegation to China and to talk about the extraordinary work that we do in termsof oversight inspection and the science around ensuring the safety of, and the quality of everything Canada exports. We're very much looking at the possibility of sending a high level delegation to China. Stephen: China claimed the situation had nothing to do with Meng Wanzhou, but a pattern began to emerge. China also moved to suspend imports of Canadian pork, and then all Canadian meat, business worth hundreds of millions of dollars each year and that's to say nothing of the human lives at stake. Canadians Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig were still jailed in China, accused of spying. [news clips play] Reporter: Very little information is trickling out on the condition of two Canadians being held by authorities in China. Reporter 2: In China, there's no coincidence, if they want to send you a message, they will send you a message. Woman: I was able to have a formal bilateral meeting with Minister Wang Yi, the Chinese foreign minister. In that meeting, I expressed Canada's very grave concern about the arbitrary detentions of Michael Kovrig and of Michael Spavor. These are two very brave Canadians who are showing remarkable grace and resilience in difficult circumstances. Stephen: But it's not just Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig, there's also Robert Schellenberg, sentenced to death for drug trafficking and then one more Canadian, Fan Wei, also sentenced to death in China in a separate drug trafficking case that emerged in April. China claimed it had legitimate reasons for all its actions, an additive found in the pork, or the actions of judges and juries beyond its control, but a foreign ministry spokesman warned Canada to take his country's concerns seriously. As Meng's lawyers point out, their allegations about abuse of process are one thing, but the very crime that their client is accused of violating sanctions against Iran, would not even be considered a crime in Canada because Canada does not have those same sanctions imposed by the United States as part of Trump's quest to isolate Iran further from the global community. Stephen: It is just one more case of Canada, a relatively small country of 37 million people, trying to establish its own identity in the presence and under the pressure of much bigger countries. As the Huawei spokesman pointed out, Canadians do value the Charter of Rights, just like they value independence, the rule of law, and the friendship of much bigger nations, and Canadians are about to ask themselves a crucial question in relation to the many things they cherish: what cost are they willing to pay to defend and uphold those values? Stephen: Coming up, on the next episode of Sanctioned: the words of a former Canadian prime minister come to haunt the current leader.  China pressures Canada to release Meng Wanzhou, while trying to stifle the protests of opponents in Hong Kong. [clip from Red Dragon plays]  Man: Whatever the Americans are claiming is a lie. Stephen: Art imitates life, as plans are announced for a movie, based on Meng Wanzhou's story.[music: somber] Stephen: I'm Stephen Quinn. Sanctioned is written by Jason Proctor, our associate producers are Vivian Luck and Rachel Sanders. It's mixed by Jeff Walter. Teresa Duvall is our executive producer and you can download episode seven at cbc.ca/podcasts or on iTunes, where you can also offer up your review. [music: somber]

title: CBC Gem - Marketplace - Are nursing homes above the law? Exposing repeat offenders
description: David Common reveals exclusive details on the state of Ontario long-term care homes before the coronavirus pandemic. Almost every home broke the law repeatedly for abuse and neglect.

title: Releasing Meng wouldn't compromise justice system, says former deputy PM
description: Former deputy prime minister John Manley says releasing Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou to secure the release of Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor would not compromise Canada’s justice system, because the attorney general has the legitimate power to intervene in extradition cases.

title: 'Very, very insensitive': Chinese Consul General Tong Xiaoling on Province headline | CBC News
description: Tong Xiaoling reacts to a front page headline in The Province newspaper that said "2nd China Virus Case in B.C."

title: John Boyega quits perfume ambassador role over Chinese ad | CBC News
description: Actor John Boyega stepped down from his role as a global ambassador for perfume brand Jo Malone on Monday after the company decided to hire a Chinese actor to replace him in an ad he created.
content: Actor John Boyega stepped down from his role as a global ambassador for perfume brand Jo Malone on Monday after the company decided to hire a Chinese actor to replace him in an ad he created.The Star Wars star, who is Black, wrote on Twitter that the brand's decision to "replace my campaign in China by using my concepts and substituting a local brand ambassador for me, without either my consent or prior notice, was wrong."Jo Malone, an upscale British perfume brand owned by Estée Lauder, has said that replacing Boyega with Chinese star Liu Haoran in the ad campaign was a misstep. It has removed the ad and apologized.The original ad starring Boyega, 28, aired last year and was called The London Gent. It features the London-born actor walking around the neighbourhood where he grew up and riding a horse in a park, and it makes reference to his Nigerian heritage in a scene featuring West African attire."The film celebrated my personal story — showcasing my hometown, including my friends and featuring my family," Boyega wrote.Their decision to replace my campaign in China by using my concepts and substituting a local brand ambassador for me, without either my consent or prior notice, was wrong. The film celebrated my personal story– showcasing my hometown, including my friends and featuring my family."While many brands understandably use a variety of global and local ambassadors, dismissively trading out one's culture this way is not something I can condone."It's not the first time Boyega has been deleted from a China-based ad. He played a leading role as Finn in 2015's Star Wars: The Force Awakens, but he and other nonwhite characters were removed or diminished from a Chinese poster for the movie.In an interview with GQ magazine, Boyega recently said that Black characters have been "pushed to the side" in Disney's Star Wars franchise. In June, the star made an emotional speech on racism when he joined Black Lives Matter protests in London.

title: Tuesday, Sept. 15, 2020: Reba McEntire, Unjoo Moon and more | CBC Radio
description: Today on q: country star Reba McEntire, director Unjoo Moon, freelance writer and artist Frankie Huang, illustrator Sydney Smith.
content: Today on q, with Tom Power:Country star Reba McEntire looks back on her career and her hit album Rumor Has It on the 30th anniversary of its release.Director Unjoo Moon talks about her new Helen Reddy film, I Am Woman, which dramatizes the Australian singer's journey from immigrant to chart-topping feminist superstar.Freelance writer and artist Frankie Huang unpacks what the controversies surrounding Disney's Mulan remake reveal about broader issues in China today, including major human rights ramifications.

title: New measurements show moon has hazardous radiation levels | CBC News
description: Future moon explorers will be bombarded with two to three times more radiation than astronauts aboard the International Space Station, a health hazard that will require thick-walled shelters for protection, scientists reported Friday.
content: Future moon explorers will be bombarded with two to three times more radiation than astronauts aboard the International Space Station, a health hazard that will require thick-walled shelters for protection, scientists reported Friday.China's lander on the far side of the moon is providing the first full measurements of radiation exposure from the lunar surface, vital information for NASA and others aiming to send astronauts to the moon, the study noted.A Chinese-German team reported on the radiation data collected by the lander — named Chang'e 4 for the Chinese moon goddess — in the U.S. journal Science Advances."This is an immense achievement in the sense that now we have a data set which we can use to benchmark our radiation" and better understand the potential risk to people on the moon, said Thomas Berger, a physicist with the German Space Agency's medicine institute.Astronauts would get 200 to 1,000 times more radiation on the moon than what we experience on Earth — or five to 10 times more than passengers on a trans-Atlantic airline flight, noted Robert Wimmer-Schweingruber of Christian-Albrechts University in Kiel, Germany."The difference is, however, that we're not on such a flight for as long as astronauts would be when they're exploring the moon," Wimmer-Schweingruber said in an email.Cancer is the primary risk."Humans are not really made for these radiation levels and should protect themselves when on the moon," he added.Radiation levels should be pretty much the same all over the moon, except for near the walls of deep craters, Wimmer-Schweingruber said."Basically, the less you see of the sky, the better. That's the primary source of the radiation," he said.Wimmer-Schweingruber said the radiation levels are close to what models had predicted. The levels measured by Chang'e 4, in fact, "agree nearly exactly" with measurements by a detector on a NASA orbiter that has been circling the moon for more than a decade, said Kerry Lee, a space radiation expert at Johnson Space Center in Houston."It is nice to see confirmation of what we think and our understanding of how radiation interacts with the moon is as expected," said Lee, who was not involved in the Chinese-led study.In a detailed outline released this week, NASA said the first pair of astronauts to land on the moon under the new Artemis program would spend about a week on the lunar surface, more than twice as long as the Apollo crews did a half-century ago. Expeditions would last one to two months once a base camp is established.NASA is looking to put astronauts on the moon by the end of 2024, an accelerated pace ordered by the White House, and on Mars sometime in the 2030s.The space agency said it will have radiation detectors and a safe shelter aboard all Orion crew capsules flying to the moon. As for the actual landers, three separate corporate teams are developing their own craft with NASA oversight. For the first Artemis moon landing, at least, the astronauts will live in the ascent portion of their lander.The German researchers suggest shelters built of moon dirt — readily available material — for stays of more than a few days. The walls should be 80 centimetres thick, they said. Any thicker and the dirt will emit its own secondary radiation, created when galactic cosmic rays interact with the lunar soil."So in this sense — I think the walls of European Castles would be too thick!" Berger wrote in an email.

title: CBC Gem - The Great British Baking Show: Masterclass - Masterclass - #2 (2011)
description: Paul and Mary show their take on the technical challenges they set for the bakers which include: Pork pies, Chocolate roulade, Iced fingers and Sachertorte.

title: CBC Gem - You Can't Ask That - Generalized Anxiety Disorder
description: Is anxiety "real"? Why don't you snap out of it? Do you hate socializing? Anxiety is gaining more social acceptance, but severe Generalized Anxiety Disorder is still sorely misunderstood.

title: Maoism: A Story of its History and Revival
description: If you thought Maoism was dead, think again. It’s enjoying a revival under President Xi Jinping. With tensions between China and the West on the rise, award- winning author Julia Lovell argues the need to understand the political legacy of Mao is crucial.

title: [Full episode] Reba McEntire, Unjoo Moon, Frankie Huang, Sydney Smith 15/09/2020
description: Country star Reba McEntire looks back on her career and her hit album Rumor Has It on the 30th anniversary of its release. Director Unjoo Moon talks about her new Helen Reddy film, I Am Woman, which dramatizes the Australian singer's journey from immigrant to chart-topping feminist superstar. Freelance writer and artist Frankie Huang unpacks what the controversies surrounding Disney's Mulan remake reveal about broader issues in China today, including major human rights ramifications. Canadian illustrator Sydney Smith discusses his latest children's book, Small in the City, which was just awarded the inaugural Sheila Barry Picture Book Award.

title: Beijing returns to increased lockdown measures
description: China is ramping up testing and lockdown measures in parts of the capital to control what seems to be its largest coronavirus outbreak in more than two months. We get the latest from Beijing correspondent Nathan VanderKlippe with The Globe and Mail.

title: More than 300 Canadians requesting repatriation from Wuhan | CBC News
description: Minister of Health Patty Hajdu discusses Canada's plan to bring back Canadians stuck in China's quarantine zone. Monte Gisborne reacts to the news that his wife and daughter will not be allowed on the plane out of China. The Power Panel and MPs debate the proposed Teck Frontier oil sands mine in Alberta.

title: Trudeau COVID-19 briefing Wednesday, May 13
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau held his daily COVID-19 briefing and took reporter questions outside Rideau Cottage on Wednesday, May 13.

title: Cycle through eerily empty streets of Wuhan, city in coronavirus quarantine | CBC News
description: Steven Li, a Toronto man living in Wuhan, took a short bike ride to get groceries. Here is what he saw.
content: Steven Li had spent 11 days holed up in his apartment in Wuhan, the Chinese city at the epicentre of the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.So on Sunday, he decided to take a short bike ride to pick up groceries."I just wanted some chocolate, to be honest," Li told CBC Radio's Metro Morning today.The experience was like being in a movie about the apocalypse, he explained."I saw probably 20 people," he said from the city of 11 million. "I saw maybe three, four cars."Watch: Take a trip through the streets of Wuhan during the city-wide quarantine:WorldThe video shows Li, who is from Toronto but currently teaching in Wuhan, cycling through the eerily quiet streets."It feels good to be outside," he can be heard saying. "There's not a lot of people. It's kind of scary, though."Every now and again, there are signs of city life. Li encounters a woman skipping rope, and others giving out bags of produce. Everyone is wearing masks and protective gear. Li says the local hospitals in Wuhan have seen shortages in medical supplies, saying they're looking for masks in particular.That's why he started raising money to help the front line medical staff and patients. And he's not the only one lending a helping hand. Aloysius Lo, chief executive of Oasis Global Partners, started an initiative to source and send medical materials to Wuhan, saying the situation there is "quite desperate."Watch: Canadian businessman describes struggle to send medical supplies to China.WorldThe initiative is aiming to send 50,000 pieces of medical equipment including gloves, goggles, masks, gowns and medical caps. "The amount of equipment we're sending over is probably able to support a hospital or two for about one or two days," Lo said. But so far, with shortages of supplies hitting Canada as well, Lo says getting their hands on the medical equipment has become increasingly difficult and expensive."We are paying about double, three times what the normal prices are," Lo said.Lo says the company is 60 per cent into its goal, and it is committed to finishing the job."We want to set an example for everyone else to help," he said. The Chinese government has reported that at least 427 people have died from coronavirus and more than 20,000 have been infected. Global Affairs Canada has chartered a flight to get about 300 people, including Canadian citizens and some permanent residents with children, out of Wuhan and Hubei province starting Thursday morning.The plane will land at the Canadian Forces base in Trenton, Ont., where all passengers and crew will spend 14 days in quarantine.Li says his spot on the flight is confirmed, and he's looking forward to heading home."It feels good," Li said. "It feels like the government is caring for their citizens. It's a nice feeling."

title: CBC.ca - Program Guide - Programs
Canadians to help develop, test potential COVID-19 vaccine from Chinese company | CBC News
description: The National Research Council of Canada said Tuesday it will work with a Chinese company to try to develop its potential vaccine for COVID-19 more quickly.
content: The National Research Council of Canada said Tuesday it will work with a Chinese company to try to develop its potential vaccine for COVID-19 more quickly.The Chinese company, CanSino Biologics, is already conducting human clinical trials for its vaccine.Federal governments the world over have said vaccines are urgently needed to allow mass gatherings to resume. But that's only if clinical trials in thousands of human volunteers show safety and efficacy before shots go into the arms of vast swaths of the general public.As of April, five vaccine candidates have moved into clinical development in early stage human trials, including CanSino's, called Ad5-nCoV.The collaboration announced on Tuesday will allow Canada's publicly funded research council to try to scale up the technology needed to produce enough of the candidate vaccine to protect Canadians.Matthew Herder, director of the Health Law Institute at Dalhousie University's law school in Halifax, evaluated contracts for the Canadian Ebola vaccine. That vaccine followed a similar path from the lab bench to mass production. Herder welcomed the NRC announcement and awaits the details."I think it showcases the power of the public sector … to play a key role in the development of vaccines," he said.There could also be strings attached on pricing, how much manufacturing can be done in Canada to meet both domestic and international needs, and equity of access, he said.The NRC plans to use a cell line its scientists developed during Ebola vaccine research.WATCH | Steps to vaccine safety and efficacy:Lakshmi Krishnan, director general of the NRC's Human Health Therapeutics Research Centre, said the trials in Canada will complement and expand on what's been done in China."We're bringing back home a Canadian technology, and we're able to have the most advanced vaccine candidate in the world potentially available for Canadians in short order," Krishnan said. A Phase 1 trial for the Ebola vaccine took place at the Canadian Centre for Vaccinology in Halifax. The coronavirus vaccine will initially also be tested on healthy human volunteers there, subject to Health Canada's approval.If successful, then Phase 2 trials could start in the fall at hospitals in other provinces with a vaccine available for non-commercial use produced on Canadian soil for front line workers and those at risk in late 2020 or early 2021, she said.Dr. Ross Upshur of the University of Toronto's Dalla Lana School of Public Health studies global health ethics. He isn't involved in the vaccine trials."You can't really tell how effective something is until you've got a large number of people and it's out in the field," Upshur said. The federal government's previously announced $44 million for upgrades to the NRC's facility in Montreal also aims to allow for domestic production if the vaccine candidate pans out.Separately on Tuesday, the federal government pledged $600 million over five years to support Gavi, a partnership between governments and the private sector. The group aims to vaccinate children around the world with routine immunizations and supports efforts to stamp out the pandemic globally.Successful vaccines normally take five to 15 years to develop and mass produce.

title: CBC Gem - Escape to the Country - Oxfordshire
description: Nicki Chapman is helping a buyer who is being supported on the house-hunt by her daughter in favour of a rural life in the Oxfordshire countryside.

title: New Brunswick goes 4 days without new cases of COVID-19 | CBC News
description: It's been four days since Public Health has seen a new case of COVID-19 in New Brunswick.
content: It's been four days since New Brunswick Public Health has seen a new case of COVID-19 in the province.There is still one active case of the respiratory virus in the Fredericton region, also known as Region 3. That person is not in hospital.Before the case was announced last Thursday, New Brunswick had gone more than two weeks without a new case.There have been 166 confirmed cases of COVID-19 since the outbreak started in March, and 163 people recover from the virus. Two people, both residents of a long-term care home in Atholville, died.So far, the province has conducted 46,489 tests for the disease, according to the dashboard information published Monday.It's been more than a week since the Atlantic travel bubble has opened between New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland.Prince Edward Island announced a new case of COVID-19 on Sunday, a health care worker at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Charlottetown. The case came to light after an 80-year-woman who had seen the health care worker at the hospital tested positive. There are currently eight active cases of the virus on the island. Nova Scotia hasn't had any new cases of COVID-19 in five consecutive days. Newfoundland recorded its first active case of COVID-19 on Friday after 43 days without any cases. No new cases of the virus have been announced over the weekend.To date, there has been 46,489 tests performed for COVID-19 in New Brunswick.People concerned they might have COVID-19 symptoms can take a self-assessment test on the government website at gnb.ca. Public Health says symptoms shown by people with COVID-19 have included: a fever above 38 C, a new cough or worsening chronic cough, sore throat, runny nose, headache, new onset of fatigue, new onset of muscle pain, diarrhea, loss of sense of taste or smell, and difficulty breathing. In children, symptoms have also included purple markings on the fingers and toes.People with one of those symptoms are asked to:Stay at home.Call Tele-Care 811 or their doctor.Describe symptoms and travel history.Follow instructions.

title: CBC Gem - CBC Docs POV - Company Town
description: When GM announces it’s closing shop in Oshawa, Ont., an embattled union and its disillusioned workers face the fight of their lives.

title: Contact tracing for COVID-19 risks erasing civil liberties, says expert | CBC Radio
description: Governments around the world are turning to new measures, including contact tracing, to try to slow the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak. This involves partnering with technology giants and collecting massive amounts of personal data from cellphones. Civil liberties organizations are worried about the potential consequences of these tradeoffs.
content: In an effort to keep the spread of the coronavirus in check, many governments around the world have granted themselves and police expanded powers. As the search for a longer-term solution continues, it raises a key question: how much are we willing to give up in the name of safety?To manage the next phase of the pandemic, governments around the world are turning to new measures, including contact tracing, to try to slow the spread of the disease. That involves partnerships with technology giants and the mass collection of personal data from cellphones. Civil liberties organizations are worried about the potential consequences of these trade-offs."When we talk about location data being particularly invasive, it's because where we are reflects who we are and how we live" said Brenda McPhail, the director of the Privacy, Technology & Surveillance Project at the Canadian Civil Liberties Association."Increasingly, in this age of surveillance capitalism, [data] can be sold and exploited, either to sell you things by corporations or to figure out how you're likely to behave," she said in an interview with Michael Enright, host of The Sunday Edition. "And it's particularly that idea of behavioural assessment … that's of particular concern, in these circumstances in the pandemic."Here are some highlights from their conversation, edited for clarity and condensed.We started out very well in Canada. We took careful, measured steps. As time goes on, as we're more and more afraid, as we're more and more sick of being stuck in our homes and social distancing, as more and more people have no employment income, the cries for governments to do more, to do anything that it takes, is getting really loud. And this is where the risks of surveillance come in. This is where we start hearing, "Any restriction is OK if it helps. So why aren't you tracking people?" Because the best way to control human behaviour is to know exactly what we do at all times.I spent all my professional life thinking about privacy and surveillance in the ways that technology affects those things. Right now, the question is absolutely, "If it will help, save lives and get us through this faster, shouldn't we just give up everything for that goal?"There's a part of me, as a mother, who is worried about her kids, as a daughter who has a mother who's in a high-risk category for this, that says I get that. I get that incredibly visceral reaction that when it comes to a choice between rights and the ability to see the faces of those I love [it] would outweigh that sort of ephemeral connection to an idea of human rights, that I think we do have in Canada. But that right now is starting to feel a little bit shaky. And maybe a little bit privileged. But the rights that form the foundation for our shared values are, in fact, the very values that are helping us get through this crisis.What's remarkable about the social effectiveness of social distancing in Canada is not how many people are getting ticketed for sitting on a bench for too long or talking across their driveway. It's how many of us are actually doing the things that we're told to do. That frankly is the response of people who live in a mature democracy. That's the response of people who share values and are willing to prioritize the common good.If we toss that out the window, even if it helps right now … we're going to reduce our ability to get through another crisis like this in the future. We're going to give up who we are and what we believe, in ways that aren't just going to risk eroding rights over the long-term. It's going to risk erasing them.With some civil liberties, we're probably pretty safe. If following this pandemic, provinces continue to limit travel, for example, there would be a huge outcry. We'd say, "No way. I have mobility rights. I deserve to travel around my home country." And that would not stand in a democracy.The problem with privacy is that we're in a situation where our idea of what privacy means — even our idea of whether or not it's a fundamental human right, which it is recognized as internationally — we are in a position where the idea that privacy is something that corporations or governments can ask us to give away in exchange for a service or convenience is really fundamental. Some of these platforms that we're using to help us navigate our way through this isolation, things like video chats, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram that are allowing us to have some form of human connection during isolation are the very platforms that have habituated us to the idea that, in exchange for the privilege of using them, they get to collect information about us.That's been fundamentally built into the infrastructure of the business model and the internet, in ways that have slowly, already eroded and changed our idea of what privacy we deserve. So the risk in the pandemic is that that process is going to accelerate. And we're going to give up — not just in relation to companies but in relation to the state — the idea that privacy is actually a right and not a privilege.You've got to watch really closely for the idea that privacy is a barrier to public health — because it's not. The reality is there is nothing in privacy law that prevents sharing of epidemiological information that's necessary for public health purposes. There is nothing in privacy law that is a barrier to lawful collection of information. And what it is is a barrier to collecting personal information that's unnecessary and intrusive, that's not proportionate to the benefit that we get from it, either as individuals or as a society.The other thing that we want to watch for is the kind of proposals about tracking our risk, about coming up with some kind of system to label us as safe or unsafe people. There are so many fundamental problems with that kind of social sorting, that it's just not a place that we should be going as Canadians.Click 'listen' above to hear the full interview.
